p.text: user-defined functions used in main code
A subshell that runs interactively has to ensure that it has been placed in the foreground by its parent shell before it can enable job control itself.
It does this by getting its initial process group ID with the getpgrp
function, and comparing it to the process group ID of the current
foreground job associated with its controlling terminal
Once the subshell has been placed into the foreground by its parent shell, it can enable its own job control.
Prompt symbol of our shell is '\m/'
The getcwd function(in unistd.h) returns an absolute file name representing the
current working directory, storing it in the character array buffer(currentDirectory)
It empties the array having the previous command stored
We are breaking the user stored text in buffer appropriately and storing that in global array of strings commandArgc
strtok(a, b) breaks string 'a' into a series of tokens using the delimiter 'b'
This function checks whether the command entered by the user belongs to built in commands defined by us. We have defined the following demands :
bg (to put a job in background)
fg (bringing a background job to foreground)
This function uses the fork() system call to create child processes in the shell and execute the commands. fork() turns a single process into 2 identical processes, known as the parent and the child.
On success, fork() returns 0 to the child process and returns the process ID of the child process to the parent process.
On failure,fork() returns -1 to the parent process,
sets errno to indicate the error, and no child process is created.
It makes use of execvp(*command, command) system call to execute commands.
Other than the commands we have defined, we can also run the inbuilt commands like ls, man, $SHELL, etc. because our shell is actually a process of the main shell. So they share the same bin.
Here cd command changes the current directory. ' ls ' is used to illustrate that cd actually works and not just only prints the changed path. Lets see how it got executed...
0 is returned when the entered command is not found in built-in.
Child process is created for cd
Process is made session leader using setpgrp()
Execution mode is foreground so tcsetpgrp() ensures no other activity occurs before completion of current process
Lets see what the parent process does in the mean time....
Parent process is put to wait till the child process is not completed if mode is foreground
In case of 'cd' descriptor is not of any use.
It will be used when we'll redirect output to some file.
After executing ' bg ' command, shell prompt is made available immediately for further working.
Using the ' jobs ', we checked the status of jobs.
This example also made use of the descriptor we talked of earlier, as the output is directed to a text file.
Lets have a look at a few functions which were not talked about but are used in this case....
